episodeTitle: Showdown on the Cliff! Red Light, Green Light!
description: The third game of the Davy Back Fight rematch begins with 'Daruma-san ga Koronda' (Red Light, Green Light), where both teams race up a cliff while sneaking up on Tonjit. Despite nearly winning, the Straw Hats lose due to various mishaps.

events.title: Red Light, Green Light Game Begins
events.description: The third event of the Davy Back Fight rematch starts: 'Daruma-san ga Koronda' (Red Light, Green Light). Teams must race up a cliff while sneaking up on Tonjit, who acts as the caller. Players must freeze when he turns around or be sent back to the start.
events.significance: Introduces another anime-exclusive game in the extended Davy Back Fight. The game tests stealth and strategy rather than direct combat, continuing the pattern of unconventional challenges.

quotes.text: The rules are simple - sneak up on me while my back is turned, but don't move when I'm looking!
quotes.speaker: Tonjit
quotes.context: Explaining the Red Light, Green Light game rules

events.title: Zoro Gets Lost on a Straight Road
events.description: Despite the race being a straight path up the cliff, Zoro somehow manages to get completely lost, wandering off in the wrong direction. This comedic moment highlights his legendary terrible sense of direction.
events.significance: A recurring gag reinforcing Zoro's character trait of being directionally challenged, even in the simplest navigation scenarios. This costs the Straw Hats valuable time and positioning.

quotes.text: How can you get lost on a straight road?!
quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami's exasperated reaction to Zoro's directional failure

events.title: Sanji Saves Porche from Drowning
events.description: When Porche falls from the cliff into the water below, Sanji immediately abandons the race to dive in and save her. His chivalrous nature takes priority over winning the game.
events.significance: Demonstrates Sanji's unwavering code of chivalry that consistently works against him in competition. The Foxy Pirates exploit this predictable weakness, knowing Sanji will always prioritize saving women over victory.

quotes.text: I can't let a beautiful lady drown!
quotes.speaker: Sanji
quotes.context: Sanji's justification for leaving the race to save Porche

events.title: Foxy Uses Noro Noro Beam
events.description: Foxy employs his Devil Fruit ability, the Noro Noro no Mi, to slow down the Straw Hats during crucial moments of the race. This gives his team an unfair advantage while technically not breaking the stated rules.
events.significance: Continues to showcase Foxy's philosophy of winning through manipulation and rule exploitation. His Devil Fruit powers become a recurring tool for gaining advantages in the Davy Back Fight games.

events.title: Nami and Usopp Nearly Reach the Top
events.description: Through clever tactics and teamwork, Nami and Usopp manage to advance further than expected, coming very close to winning the game for the Straw Hats. They demonstrate strategic thinking that nearly overcomes the Foxy Pirates' cheating.
events.significance: Highlights Nami and Usopp's strengths in strategy and coordination, showing that the Straw Hats could win these games if not for various mishaps and the Foxy Pirates' underhanded tactics.

quotes.speaker: Nami
quotes.context: Nami's encouragement as they near victory

events.title: Foxy Pirates Win Red Light, Green Light
events.description: Despite the Straw Hats' best efforts, the Foxy Pirates win the Red Light, Green Light game through a combination of Foxy's Devil Fruit powers, the Straw Hats' various mishaps, and strategic manipulation of the rules.
events.significance: Marks the second consecutive loss for the Straw Hats in the rematch, putting them at a significant disadvantage. This continues the pattern of the Foxy Pirates winning through cunning rather than strength.

quotes.text: Fe fe fe fe! Victory is ours once again!
quotes.speaker: Foxy
quotes.context: Foxy's celebration after winning the game

events.title: Chopper Taken by Foxy Pirates Again
events.description: As the prize for winning the Red Light, Green Light game, Foxy chooses to take Tony Tony Chopper from the Straw Hat Pirates once again. Chopper must temporarily join the Foxy Pirates for the second time during this rematch.
events.significance: Creates emotional stakes and urgency for the remaining games. Chopper's repeated capture demonstrates the real consequences of losing these seemingly silly games and motivates the crew to win him back.

themes.description: The episode highlights how each Straw Hat's defining characteristics can become exploitable weaknesses. Zoro's terrible sense of direction and Sanji's chivalry actively work against the team's success.
themes.symbolism: The game itself represents how knowing your opponent's weaknesses can be more valuable than raw power, a recurring theme in the Foxy Pirates arc.

culturalReferences.description: The Japanese children's game equivalent to 'Red Light, Green Light' or 'Statues,' which is a traditional playground game about stealth and self-control.

themes.description: Despite being physically stronger, the Straw Hats continue to lose games that require strategic thinking and rule manipulation. The episode demonstrates that different types of challenges require different skills.
themes.symbolism: The cliff race symbolizes the uphill battle the Straw Hats face when competing on the Foxy Pirates' terms rather than their own.

themes.description: The repeated loss of Chopper emphasizes the emotional and practical stakes of the Davy Back Fight. The crew's determination to win him back showcases their bond.
themes.symbolism: Chopper being taken multiple times represents the vulnerability of even the strongest crews when they're forced to play by another pirate's rules.

mangaDifferences.difference: The entire Red Light, Green Light game is anime-only filler content. In the manga, the Davy Back Fight proceeds directly from the Groggy Ring match to the final combat event without these intermediate games.

In the manga, Chopper is only taken once during the Donut Race and won back during the Combat round. The anime's addition of multiple games creates a pattern of repeatedly losing and regaining Chopper that doesn't exist in the source material.
The specific game 'Daruma-san ga Koronda' and its cliff-climbing variant are entirely anime inventions to extend the arc beyond its manga length.

trivia.fact: The game 'Daruma-san ga Koronda' literally translates to 'the Daruma doll fell down' and is the Japanese equivalent of the Western children's game 'Red Light, Green Light' or 'Statues.'

This episode, along with episodes 213-215, were created as anime filler to prevent the anime from catching up to the manga. At the time, Oda was just beginning the Water 7 arc and needed time to get ahead.

sources.title: Long Ring Long Land Arc - One Piece Wiki

trivia.fact: The Long Ring Long Land arc is one of the most divisive arcs in One Piece, with the anime's filler games significantly contributing to its negative reputation among fans.

sources.title: One Piece's Most Hated Story Was Actually Ruined By The Anime

trivia.fact: Despite being filler, this episode maintains continuity with the manga's core events and doesn't contradict canon material, making it skippable but not non-canonical.
The episode aired on the same date in Japan (January 9, 2005) as Episode 215, suggesting it may have been a double-episode broadcast or rapid sequential airing.
